meta.title: Forensic Medicine - INI CET NOVEMBER 2022 (PART - A)

questions.text: Spanish windlass technique, a type of mechanical asphyxia is also known as:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Garrotting Spanish windlass technique, a type of mechanical asphyxia, is also known as Garrotting.

Highyeild:

Garrotting: Type of asphyxia in which the throat may be grasped , or a ligature is thrown over the neck and quickly tightened , by twisting it with a lever, within the ligature , which results in sudden loss of consciousness and Garrotting as a mode of judicial execution was once employed in Spain. An iron collar around the neck was tightened by a screw for strangling (Spanish Windlash). Garrotting was used by thugs around 1862 in India. A rope or a loincloth is suddenly thrown over the head and quickly tightened around the neck.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Bansdola- is a form of strangulation practised in north India. Strong bamboo is placed across the throat and another across the back of the neck . Option B. Mugging- When strangulation is brought about by compressing the throat with a foot, knee, bend of elbow, or some other solid substances, it is known as mugging (stranglehold). Option D. Strangulation- is defined as the compression of the neck by a force other than hanging . Weight of the body has nothing to do with strangulation.

Table:

#MANTRA Mechanical Asphyxia: Asphyxia : absence of pulse (literal meaning) . Exclusion of air from the lungs. Hypoxia : Deprivation of adequate oxygen supply at the tissue level, which is produced by asphyxia. Anoxia : Complete deprivation of oxygen at tissue level. Classification of violent asphyxial deaths: Hanging Complete hanging- no part of the body touching the ground. Partial /incomplete hanging- some part of the body touching the ground. Typical- knot at back of neck Atypical- knot anywhere other than back. Strangulation Ligature strangulation Throttling Bansdola Garrotting Mugging Suffocation Smothering Gagging Choking Crush asphyxia/ traumatic asphyxia Bansdola Burking Drowning Typical drowning (wet) Salt water Fresh water Atypical drowning Dry drowning - sustained laryngeal spasm Hydrocution- sudden cardiac arrest on entering water. Near secondary drowning- patient dies after rescue due to secondary complication of drowning .

questions.text: One forcep was left in the abdomen after surgery. What does this implicate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Res ipsa loquitur Pair of surgical scissors left behind in the abdomen after surgery . The offence comes under res ipsa loquitur .

Highyeild:

Res ipsa loquitur- In doctrine of Res ipsa loquitur , the facts of the case are sufficient to justify the conclusion that doctor was negligent and negligence of doctor is responsible for the harm suffered by the patient. Examples of Res ipsa loquitur are as follows: 1. Amputation of wrong digit or limb Leaving a swab or instrument in the abdomen of the patient after operation. Giving medicine carelessly or prescribing overdose of medicines produces ill effects. "Res ipsa loquitur" means "the thing or fact speaks for itself." The negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence . This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Novus actus interveniens -It means an unrelated action intervening At times, it occurred that patients might suffer damage or harm due to new action , which intervene or intercede the For example – suppose an operated patient is shifted to a recovery room and suddenly, due to an earthquake , the ceiling falls over the patient and the patient dies in the accident. Here the falling of the ceiling is a new intervention that has occurred. A doctor may not be held responsible if damage occurred to a patient due to new action, which intervenes in the treatment. Option C. Res judicata -If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided in court , the patient will not be allowed to contest the same in another court based Multiple appeals cannot be made. Option D. The principle of respondeat superior- says that the employer is responsible for employees negligence .

Extraedge:

Penal Provisions Applicable To Medical Practice: I.P.C. S. 52 Nothing is said to be done in good faith which is done without due care and attention. S. 191 Giving false evidence. S. 192 Fabricating false evidence. S. 193 Punishment for false evidence (imprisonment up to seven years). S. 194 Giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure conviction of capital offence (imprisonment up to ten years ). S. 195 Giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure conviction of offence (imprisonment for life or imprisonment. ) S. 197 Issuing or signing false certificates ( imprisonment up to seven years ). S. 201 Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offenders ( imprisonment up to ten years ). S. 202 Intentional omission to give information of offence by person bound to inform ( imprisonment up to six months ). S. 203 Giving false information respecting an offence committed (imprisonment up to two years ). S. 204 Destruction of document to prevent its production as evidence (imprisonment up to two years). S. 269 Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life (imprisonment up to six months ). S. 270 Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life (imprisonment up to two years ). S. 284 Negligent conduct with respect to poisonous substances .(imprisonment upto 6 months ).

Table:

#MANTRA Defenses against negligence for doctor- No duty owed to the patient Duty discharged as per prevailing / accepted standards Contributory Negligence (only for civil cases) Patient Negligence Medical Maloccurrence Therapeutic Misadventure Diagnostic Misadventure Experimental Misadventure Novus Actus Interveniens Res Judicata 11 . Res Indicata Calculated Risk doctrine Defenses for patient against Doctor : Res Ipsa Loquitur : The thing / fact speaks for itself Doctrine of common knowledge : Issue of negligence is not related to the expert knowledge of doctors, but rather it is due to lack of common sense.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardiac poison:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atropa Belladonna Atropa belladonna is a deliriant poison that acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine .

Highyeild:

Atropa Belladonna- All the parts of the plants are toxic. Active principle: Leaves of the plant contain high levels of alkaloids, namely atropine, scopolamine and hyoscyamine . Alkaloids in its structure competitively block the postganglionic parasympathetic muscarinic receptors and the muscarinic receptors in the central nervous system. Clinical manifestations - Fever, flushing, rash Neurological symptoms - delirium , slurred speech, headache, choreoathetosis, myoclonus, visual and auditory hallucinations , convulsions, and coma Eye symptoms - photophobia, blurred vision, dilated pupils poorly reactive to light Cardiovascular symptoms - arrhythmia, tachycardia, hypertension Gastrointestinal symptoms - severely dry mouth and throat, decreased bowel sounds, constipation, ileus Renal symptoms - urinary retention Anticholinergic symptoms include tachycardia, hypertension, flushing, dry mouth, mydriasis, and urinary retention . Antidote- Physostigmine.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, B and C. are cardiac poison.

Table:

#MANTRA Cardiac poison:

questions.text: Skin tattooing around the entry wound from a gun of a bullet is due to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unburnt particles Tattooing -Partly burnt/unburnt gun powder particles.Around entry wound, they are adherent to the skin. It cannot be wiped away and felt as sharpones. This is called tattooing / stippling / peppering.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.Flame- causes singing of hair,scorching of Option B.Smoke- Causes Blackening of epidermis (can be wiped away). Option C.Muzzle impression- is seen in contact shot.

Table:

#MANTRA Range of firearm weapon: Range of firearm weapon distant wise- Firearm weapon Flame Smoke Unburned gunpowder particles Singing seen till Blackening seen till Tattooing seen till short arm rifled weapon (pistol and revolver) 7.5 cm 15 cm 30 cm Long arm rifled weapon 15 cm 30cm 60cm Shotgun (smooth bore firearm) 30 cm 60 cm 90cm

Solution:

Abrasion Abrasion , also known as gravel rash, is the destruction of superficial layers of the epidermis . It is caused by friction against a rough surface or by compression.

Highyeild:

Abrasions are injuries in which there is destruction of skin involving only the superficial layers of epidermis. Mechanism: Caused when there is lateral friction of skin against rough surface. Simple injuries which bleed less, heal rapidly without any formation of scars. Types : 4 types Scratch Graze Pressure Imprint Scratch : Scratch is a linear abrasion which has a significant length and insignificant breadth /width. Very superficial incised wounds. Eg: Fingernail scratch Graze : C type of abrasion C type of abrasion in RTA Produced when a larger area of skin is frictioned against a large rough surface. Eg : Body is dragged along road Multiple small linear abrasions, tip of these abrasions have epidermal skin Indicates direction of force. Pressure Abrasions: The force causing the abrasion is perpendicular to skin and exerted for a long time. Smaller force exerted for a long time. Eg : ligature mark, bite marks Imprint / Impact Abrasions : They are produced when a larger force is applied perpendicular to the skin for a short interval (momentarily). Eg : Tyre marks, marks of radiator grill,headlamp Age of Abrasion- Fresh – Bright red 12 – 24 hrs – Bright red scab 2 – 3 days – Reddish brown scab 4 – 7 days – Brownish black scab >7 days – Scab falls – Depigmented area.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B.Contusion and Option C.Bruise - characterised by the infiltration of extravasated blood into the subcutaneou s and/or subepithelial tissues. It results from the rupture of small blood vessels due to the application of blunt force. Option D.Laceration- refers to a tear or split of the skin, mucous membranes, muscle, or internal organs. It is due to the application of blunt force to a broad area of the body. They are also called tears or ruptures.

Extraedge:

D/B Antemortem and Postmortem abrasions CRITERIA ANTEMORTEM POSTMORTEM Color Bright, reddish brown Yellow, translucent, Parchment like Vital reaction Inflammatory reaction with cellular infiltration seen Not seen

questions.text: Match the following related to eruption of teeth in adults? Choose the correct Answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1 Option A is the correct match as explained below.

Highyeild:

Tooth eruption is the movement of the developing tooth from its non-functional position in the alveolar bone to its final functional position in the oral cavity. Temporary teeth (IM CM) Age Incisors 6 month First molar 12 month Canine 18 month Second molar 24-30 month Permanent teeth (Mama Is In Pain Papa Can Make Medicine) yr Teeth year 1 st molar 6 central incisor 7 Lateral incisor 8 First premolar 9 second premolar 10 Canine 11 Second molar 12-14 Third molar 18-25

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B,C and D. are not the correct match.

Table:

#MANTRA Gustafson method- Determines age from teeth. 25-60 year (APSRTC) A-attrition P-periodontitis S-secondary dentine formation R-root resorption T-Transparency of root→ Most reliable criteria C-Cementum apposition

questions.text: Match the following: Choose the correct Answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3 Option B. is a correct match for Paraphilias as explained below.

Highyeild:

Paraphilias or perversions are sexual stimuli or acts that are deviations from normal sexual behaviors but are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm. Eonism (also known as transvestism )- is a sexual perversion, where a person's whole personality is dominated by a desire to b e identified as a member of the opposite sex . This is usually seen in males who obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female clothes Exhibitionism -is the urge to expose genitals to a stranger or unsuspecting person. Frotteurism- refers to the sexual gratification achieved by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person . This behavior often occurs in busy and crowded places. It is predominantly described in Necrophilia - is an obsession with obtaining sexual gratification from dead bodies. DSM-5 specified paraphilic disorders Disorder Atypical sexual interest Voyeuristic disorder Observing an unsuspecting person who is naked, disrobing, or engaging in sexual activity Exhibitionistic disorder Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting person Frotteuristic disorder Touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person Sexual masochism disorder Being humiliated, beaten, bound, or otherwise made to suffer Sexual sadism disorder Physical or psychological suffering of another person Pedophilic disorder Prepubescent children Fetishistic disorder Nonliving objects or nongenital body parts Transvestic disorder Cross-dressing

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A,C and D. are not matched correctly.

Table:

#MANTRA I.P.C. dealing with sexual offence S.357 (C) Hospital role for victims of sexual assault and acid attack--- first-aid for victims to be free of cost & if Hospital refuses ---punishable under 166 B IPC S.375 Definition of rape S.376 Punishment for rape S.376C Sexual intercourse by a person in authority. S.290 Frotteurism S.294 Exhibitionism S.297 Showing disrespect to dead body(1yr) S.376E repeat offender S.327(2) Enquiry/trial under sec 376 IPC will be done under camera. S.228-A revealing the identity of rape victim is crime. S.354 Indecent assault/ molestation S.354A sexual harassment S.354B Assault or use of criminal force to woman with intent to disrobe S.354C Voyeurism S.354D Stalking S.504 Word, Gesture or act to insult the modesty of a women CrPC53A rape accused examination (Consent not required) CrPC164 A rape victim examination (consent of victim must)

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in cold water Drowning? -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vasovagal Inhibition The most common cause of death in cold water Drowning is Vasovagal Inhibition because cold water stimulates nerve endings & water striking epigastrium causes Vagal inhibition → Cardiac arrest → death.

Highyeild:

Types of drowning- Wet drowning- primary drowning Dry drowning - 10-15%, laryngospasm , thick mucous→foam plug, panoramic views of past life, pleasant dreams without distress. Secondary drowning/post immersion syndromes /near drowning: Secondary drowning is death due to chemical or biological changes in the lungs after a near drowning incident : resuscitated an survives for 24 hours , +/- conscious, hypoxemia→ brain damage , electrolyte disturbances, pulmonary edema, hemoglobinuria, chemical pneumonitis Immersion syndrome / Cold water drowning : Cold water → Nerve endings ,strike epigastrium,entering ear drums, nasal passages. Horizontal entry (dive) → pressure on abdomen All these → Vagal inhibition → Cardiac arrest → death Mostly seen in suicide cases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B.Cardiac Arrest-Vasovagal Inhibition is more specific. Option C.Hyperkalemia and Hemodilution - is seen in fresh water drowning. Option D.Laryngospasm -is seen in dry drowning.

Table:

#MANTRA Mechanical Asphyxia- Asphyxia : absence of pulse (literal meaning) . Exclusion of air from the lungs. Hypoxia : Deprivation of adequate oxygen supply at the tissue level, which is produced by asphyxia. Anoxia : Complete deprivation of oxygen at tissue level. Classification of violent asphyxial deaths- Hanging Complete hanging- no part of the body touching the ground. Partial /incomplete hanging- some part of the body touching the ground. Typical- knot at back of neck Atypical- knot anywhere other than back. Strangulation Ligature strangulation Throttling Bansdola Garrotting Mugging Suffocation Smothering Gagging Choking Crush asphyxia/ traumatic asphyxia Bansdola Burking Drowning Typical drowning (wet) Salt water Fresh water Atypical drowning Dry drowning - sustained laryngeal spasm Hydrocution- sudden cardiac arrest on entering water. Near secondary drowning- patient dies after rescue due to secondary complication of drowning .
